work.p: This manuscript may describe Whitman's plan for what eventually became section 9 of the poem titled "I Sing the Body Electric." This section, beginning with the words "O my body!", was added to the poem in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass.

titleStmt.title: A poem in which is
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the mid-1850s. It may describe what eventually became section 9 of the poem titled "I Sing the Body Electric." Although a version of that poem, titled "Leaves of Grass," appeared in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, that section was first added to the poem in the 1856 edition of Leaves. Edward Grier speculates that the pink paper used for this manuscript may have been a wrapper from the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which if true would date this manuscript to 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Suggestions for Poems: "A poem in which is minutely described..."
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

div1.p: A poem which is minutely described the whole particulars and ensemble of a first-rate healthy Human Body—is looked into and through, as if it were transparent and of pure glass—and now reported in a poem—
Read the latest and best anatomical works
also casts and figures in the collections of design
